segment.source: Test Your Migration (Windows 10)
segment.target: Test Your Migration (Windows 10)

segment.source: Test Your Migration
segment.target: Test Your Migration

segment.source: Test Your Migration
segment.target: Test Your Migration

segment.source: Always test your migration plan in a controlled laboratory setting before you deploy it to your entire organization.
segment.target: Always test your migration plan in a controlled laboratory setting before you deploy it to your entire organization.

segment.source: In your test environment, you need at least one computer for each type of operating system from which you are migrating data.
segment.target: In your test environment, you need at least one computer for each type of operating system from which you are migrating data.

segment.source: After you have thoroughly tested the entire migration process on a single computer running each of your source operating systems, conduct a pilot migration with a small group of users.
segment.target: After you have thoroughly tested the entire migration process on a single computer running each of your source operating systems, conduct a pilot migration with a small group of users.

segment.source: After migrating a few typical user states to the intermediate store, note the space required and adjust your initial calculations accordingly.
segment.target: After migrating a few typical user states to the intermediate store, note the space required and adjust your initial calculations accordingly.

segment.source: For details about estimating the space needed for your migration, see Estimate Migration Store Size.
segment.target: For details about estimating the space needed for your migration, see Estimate Migration Store Size.

segment.source: You might also need to adjust the registry-setting and file-location information in your migration-rule files.
segment.target: You might also need to adjust the registry-setting and file-location information in your migration-rule files.

segment.source: If you make changes, test the migration again.
segment.target: If you make changes, test the migration again.

segment.source: Then verify that all data and settings have migrated as expected.
segment.target: Then verify that all data and settings have migrated as expected.

segment.source: A pilot migration also gives you an opportunity to test your space estimates for the intermediate store.
segment.target: A pilot migration also gives you an opportunity to test your space estimates for the intermediate store.

segment.source: If your test migration encounters any errors, examine the ScanState and LoadState logs to obtain the exact User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 return code and associated error messages or Windows application programming interface (API) error message.
segment.target: If your test migration encounters any errors, examine the ScanState and LoadState logs to obtain the exact User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 return code and associated error messages or Windows application programming interface (API) error message.

segment.source: For more information about USMT return codes and error messages, see Return Codes.
segment.target: For more information about USMT return codes and error messages, see Return Codes.

segment.source: You can also obtain more information about a Windows API error message by typing net helpmsg and the error message number on the command line.
segment.target: You can also obtain more information about a Windows API error message by typing net helpmsg and the error message number on the command line.

segment.source: In most cases, the ScanState and LoadState logs indicate why a USMT migration is failing.
segment.target: In most cases, the ScanState and LoadState logs indicate why a USMT migration is failing.

segment.source: We recommend that you use the /v:5 option when testing your migration.
segment.target: We recommend that you use the /v:5 option when testing your migration.

segment.source: This verbosity level can be adjusted in a production migration.
segment.target: This verbosity level can be adjusted in a production migration.

segment.source: Reducing the verbosity level might make it more difficult to diagnose failures that are encountered during production migrations.
segment.target: Reducing the verbosity level might make it more difficult to diagnose failures that are encountered during production migrations.

segment.source: You can use a higher verbosity level if you want the log files output to go to a debugger.
segment.target: You can use a higher verbosity level if you want the log files output to go to a debugger.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Running the ScanState and LoadState tools with the /v:5 option creates a detailed log file.
segment.target: Running the ScanState and LoadState tools with the /v:5 option creates a detailed log file.

segment.source: Although this option makes the log file large, it is helpful in determining where migration errors occurred.
segment.target: Although this option makes the log file large, it is helpful in determining where migration errors occurred.

segment.source: After you have determined that the pilot migration successfully migrated the specified files and settings, you are ready to add USMT to the server that is running Microsoft® System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM), or a non-Microsoft management technology.
segment.target: After you have determined that the pilot migration successfully migrated the specified files and settings, you are ready to add USMT to the server that is running Microsoft® System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM), or a non-Microsoft management technology.

segment.source: For more information, see Configuration Manager.
segment.target: For more information, see Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For testing purposes, you can create an uncompressed store using the /hardlink /nocompress option.
segment.target: For testing purposes, you can create an uncompressed store using the /hardlink /nocompress option.

segment.source: When compression is disabled, the ScanState tool saves the files and settings to a hidden folder named "File" at StorePathUSMT.
segment.target: When compression is disabled, the ScanState tool saves the files and settings to a hidden folder named "File" at StorePathUSMT.

segment.source: You can use the uncompressed store to view what USMT has stored or to troubleshoot a problem, or you can run an antivirus utility against the files.
segment.target: You can use the uncompressed store to view what USMT has stored or to troubleshoot a problem, or you can run an antivirus utility against the files.

segment.source: Additionally, you can also use the /listfiles command-line option and the diagnostic log to list the files that were gathered and to troubleshoot problems with your migration.
segment.target: Additionally, you can also use the /listfiles command-line option and the diagnostic log to list the files that were gathered and to troubleshoot problems with your migration.
